Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Doctoral Symposium at the Sixth International Conference on the Theory and Application of Diagrams

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diagrams are very wide-ranging and open-ended representations that include sketches, drawings, graphs, pictures, 2D and 3D geometric models, visualizations and animations. Diagrammatic representations significantly impact many aspects of human life and society ranging from art to science, from communication to education. The emerging science of visual analytics, which focuses on interactive use of diagrammatic representations for supporting human problem solving, is just one topical example of the need for studying diagrammatic representations and reasoning. In fact, there is a need for transformative advances in (1) understanding diagrammatic reasoning in humans, (2)understanding the use of diagrammatic representation for communication and collaboration among humans, (3) developing techniques for automated diagrammatic reasoning, and (4) designing interactive environments for use of diagrammatic representations for supporting human reasoning.

This project provides support for the Doctoral Student Symposium at the Sixth International Conference on the Theory and Application of Diagrams in Portland Oregon on August 11-14, 2010. The goal of the 1-day Doctoral Symposium is to provide senior doctoral students as well as recent Master's and Doctoral graduates engaged in research with an opportunity to present their work and get feedback from established researchers in the field. A group of experts will be present to comment on the young researchers? presentations in an informal and constructive environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diagrammatic reasoning refers to reasoning about and with diagrams such as sketches and drawings, both in humans and computers. The International Conference on the Theory and Applications of Diagrams are the premier international conference series on diagrammatic reasoning. These biennial bring together scientists from across the world for presentation, demonstration and discussion of the latest, state of art research, including both established experts and graduate students.

We held a Graduate Student Symposium with the Sixth International Conference on the Theory and Application of Diagrams (Diagrams-2010) in Portland, Oregon, on Monday, August 9th, 2010. The GSS was organized by Professor Jim Davies. Other faculty advisers at the GSS included Professors Ashok Goel, Unmesh Kurup, Mateja Jamnik and Hari Narayanan. Fourteen graduate students participated in the GSS, gave short talks, and interacted with the faculty advisers and other participants. The GSS website is located at <http://www.diagrams-conference.org/2010/content/graduate-symposium.html>. The website lists all the graduate students at the GSS and the titles of their talks.

Diagrammatic reasoning is an interdisciplinary research community, including art, computer science, design, education, information science, philosophy, and psychology. The fourteen students attending the Diagrams-2010 GSS learned about how to do interdisciplinary research and how to present a paper to an interdisciplinary audience. For some of the students, this was their first experience at a major research conference. The GSS provided them with a friendly, constructive setting for presentations and interactions. The students also heard talks on how to write a good Ph.D. dissertation. Thus, the GSS enhanced research training of the fourteen student participants, especially in regard to interdisciplinary research in diagrammatic reasoning.
